Working with the Change Request List

When you click the Change Requests tab, a list of change requests displays in the upper pane of the project view window. The Change Request menu item also becomes available on the menu bar.

All change requests shown in the upper pane:

  • Are attached to the folder selected from the application folder hierarchy.

  • Match the filter selected from the Filter drop-down list box.

  • Match the depth specified by the All Descendants button.

Using the Change Request List

From the Change Request list, you can perform a variety of operations, including:

View unread items

To see the change requests for which you are responsible but have not reviewed, look for the change requests in boldface type. The change requests in regular type are those that you have read or those for which you are not responsible.

View properties

To see the properties of a specific change request, double-click it.

Review change request type

Look at the icons associated with a specific change request to determine its type. The icon that appears indicates whether the change request is for a defect or a suggestion.

Review change request status

Look at the icons associated with a specific change request to determine its current status. Possible statuses are:

  • New

  • Open

  • In Progress

  • Deferred

  • Cannot Reproduce

  • As Designed

  • Fixed

  • Documented

  • Is Duplicate

Additional icons indicate whether the Cannot Reproduce, As Designed, Fixed, Documented, and Is Duplicate items have been Resolved, Fixed, or Closed.

Review change request severity level

The severity level may be High, Medium, or Low. It is also indicated by specific icons.

Move change request

To move a change request from one application folder to another, drag it to the new folder. See Moving, Sharing, and Branching Change Requests.

Share change requests

To share a change request in one application folder with another folder, press Ctrl, then drag the change request to the second folder. You can also share change requests with other views or projects, as long as they use the same server configuration. See Moving, Sharing, and Branching Change Requests.

Filter data

You can rearrange fields, show different fields, use group bands, and apply queries to the data in the Change Request list. You can also save the operations you have performed on the data as a query or filter. To perform these actions from the context menu, right-click a column header to display the menu.

Sort change requests

You can click a column header to sort the displayed change requests based on the value in that column. The sort is usually in ascending numeric or alphanumeric order, depending on the data. The ascending order for Severity goes from Low to Medium to High. The ascending order for Status reflects the life cycle of the change request, so it goes from New to Closed. The ascending order for Priority goes from No to Yes.

To change the sort order from ascending to descending, click the header a second time. A triangle indicating the direction of the sort appears on the header of the primary sort column.

Default columns on the Change Request list are:

  • CR Number: Number that the application assigned to the change request when it was first submitted.

  • Synopsis: Short explanation of the change request.

  • Type: Defect or Suggestion.

  • Status: Indication of the change request life cycle. Status classifications include New, Open, In Progress, Deferred, Resolved, Verified Closed, Cannot Reproduce, As Designed, Fixed, Documented, Is Duplicate.

  • Severity: Seriousness of the change request. Severity can be High, Medium, or Low.

  • Responsibility: Person who is responsible for the change request.

  • Addressed In: Build in which the change request is resolved.

  • Addressed In View: View in which the change request has been resolved. This information is important for shared and moved change requests.

  • Addressed By: Name of user who resolved the change request. A change request has been resolved when its status becomes Cannot Reproduce, As Designed, Fixed, Documented, or Is Duplicate.

  • Last Build Tested: Build in which the change request occurs.

  • Work Around: Solution to a change request other than a fix.

  • Modified Time: Time the change request was last modified.

  • Priority: Indication that the change request is or is not a Priority.

  • Description: Complete explanation of the defect or suggestion, including the steps to be taken to reproduce the problem.

  • Test Command: Command that can be used to test the change request’s solution.

  • Fix: Solution to the problem addressed by the change request.

  • Entered On: Date and time the change request was submitted.

  • Entered By: Person who submitted the change request.

Refresh view

Press Shift + F5 to refresh the entire view (all items on all tabs as well as the application folder hierarchy). Press F5 to refresh only the Change Request list. Press Ctrl + F5 to refresh the Change Request list and collapse all open groups simultaneously.
